stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session sketch-planning the late-game Ice Castle course for “Return to Yoshi’s Island,” hashing out visuals, mechanics, star objectives, and overall layout while live-testing reflective ice wall techniques and discussing new low-level engine work.

development_findings.summary: The course will have six stars: (1) outside red-coin mission, (2) ‘seen-but-unreachable’ foyer star reached after castle traversal, (3) cold-haze basement gauntlet with fire safe-spots, (4) 8-bit pipe star themed after Mario Land 1, (5) sliding/platforming gauntlet, (6) Raven boss fight on the roof.
development_findings.quote: I wanted cold haze rooms in the basement… and Star Three is obviously the boss fight with the Raven.

development_findings.summary: Level mood aims for a lonely, eerie, late-game feel comparable to Tick Tock Clock, with dark-blue / light-blue / white palette and minimal NPCs (scared penguins outside).
Preliminary geometry evolved from a U-shape to an H-shape castle with two tall towers linked by a bridge; foyer stairs are deliberately slippery so players must find an alternate path upward.
development_findings.quote: I like the idea of towers in front and back and a bridge connecting them—yes, let’s do that.

development_findings.summary: Planned mechanics include: CPU-generated ice reflections, ice-wave ‘surf’ platforms, rotating hexagonal ice slabs that redirect wall jumps, wind gusts, appearing paths (Galaxy-style), cracking ice blocks, and sliding ice cubes over spikes.
Enemy roster: Yoshi’s Island Ravens (boss & mobs), big rolling-head snowman, ice-block ‘Nappa’ giant, plus ambient wind and hazard systems.

Kaze is prototyping a camera-dependent shiny-wall shader as fallback to true normal-map reflections; limitation is six wall orientations and N64 RGBA16 quantization, so IA8 + animated combiner is being tested.
development_findings.quote: It would actually look like ice cubes… but we can only do six walls at the same time unless we program every direction individually.

development_findings.summary: He wrote a new custom OS (rewrite of LibUltra) for N64, already functional and giving more control and potential optimisations.
development_findings.quote: Did I tell you guys that I wrote a new OS for my N64? It’s all done now—it gives me a lot more control.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is beta-testing NEMU64, calling it the most accurate emulator he’s used; not public yet.
development_findings.quote: NEMU isn’t publicly released yet—I’m just testing it for him, and I like using it.

development_findings.summary: Target release plan floated: simultaneous PC (decomp) and N64 ROM release for marketing impact.
development_findings.quote: A goal would be to release on PC and N64 at the same time—that’s some insane advertising.

development_findings.summary: Kaze confirms eventual public source-code release despite community doubts.
development_findings.quote: Yes, the source code will release—despite what people seem to think.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy: labyrinthine paths should feel confusing but never frustrating; every branch eventually moves the player forward.
context_findings.quote: It’s going to feel confusing, but not frustrating is the goal here.

context_findings.summary: Shows pride and excitement over low-level technical challenges (new OS, ice reflections) yet frustration with Twitch bot raids and texture quantisation.
Personal note: Zeina (wife/animator) cut Kaze’s hair badly, forcing him to nearly shave it; casual banter about spouse and family.
context_findings.quote: My wife just kind of messed up my hair and now I look like this.

biobak.summary: Collaborated off-stream to establish the castle’s art style and provided shiny ice-brick textures that Kaze prefers over his own tests.
biobak.quote: It just looks better because Biobak touched it and not me.

zeina.summary: Created an icy-brick model combiner for walls and is currently modelling the Raven boss.
zeina.quote: Zeina made an icy bricks combiner… Zeina’s making the Raven. That looks pretty nice.

key_stories.title: Settling on Reflective Ice Walls
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak experiment live with multiple texture/combiner setups to fake ice reflections within N64 limits. After wrestling with RGBA16 artefacts, they land on an IA8 plus scrolling-shine solution.
key_stories.challenge: Achieving convincing reflective ice on limited N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Tried CPU-generated normal maps, discovered six-wall limit and heavy cost; tested shiny texture with camera-dependent scroll; fought colour-banding from quantisation.
key_stories.outcome: Adopted hybrid technique (IA8 texture + animated combiner) as practical baseline; may still explore CPU normals where affordable.
key_stories.key_quote: Quantisation really messed us up… but this IA8 scroll actually looks pretty frosty.

key_stories.title: Writing a Custom N64 OS
key_stories.summary: Off-stream, Kaze stripped LibUltra to essentials and rebuilt it to gain tighter control and speed, promising future optimisations for the hack.
key_stories.challenge: Need for performance headroom and flexibility beyond stock LibUltra.
key_stories.process: Removed unnecessary LibUltra modules, rebuilt only needed subsystems, planning further optimisation passes.
key_stories.outcome: New OS already functional; expected to unlock significant optimisations across the project.
key_stories.key_quote: I kinda just took LibUltra and ripped out only the parts I needed.

key_stories.title: Re-shaping the Ice Castle Layout
key_stories.summary: Initial U-shaped plan felt limited; during stream brainstorming, Kaze sketches an H-shaped castle with a bridge, giving every room clearer purpose and dramatic skyline.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a castle layout that supports all planned rooms and star routes.
key_stories.process: Drew block diagrams, considered pathing, integrated outside 8-bit pipe and snowman cave, adjusted foyer and towers.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on H-shape with front/back towers, central foyer, basement, bridge, and external cave—provides logical flow for all six stars.
key_stories.key_quote: Towers in front and back and a bridge connecting them—yes, let’s do that.
